title: Thursday, 2nd March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:03am

Our daily chat about stuff

PM11:04am

Big rally yesterday

11:03 am

Big rally

PM11:04am

And today...

PM11:07am

11:07 am

PM11:08am

BE11:09am

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Here's mine for the past hour. Knock yourself out.

BE11:09am

hehehe

11:09 am

Anyway, yes, we're flat.

BE11:10am

You can blame the House of Lords, as several of those emails are doing ............

PM11:10am

Seriously? What else did the market expect the Lords to do?

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Well exactly. Or you can blame the rush to a record high yesterday on Trumpflation, a probable US rate hike in March, a weaker GBK and whatever else.

PM11:11am

I have a quick Brexit summary if that helps

BE11:11am

Please! I'd like nothing more!

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Let me deliver some Malcolm Barr then

PM11:11am

JPM of course

PM11:12am

Passing the Article 50 bill. The House of Lords has voted in favour of one amendment to the bill (regarding rights of EU citizens in the UK), and there is a possibility of another being adopted (on the ability of parliament to vote on the deal). The amended bill will go back to the House of Commons where it is very likely the amendments will be rejected, sending the bill back to Lords. Reports suggest that the Lords will not attempt to amend the bill a second time. As a result, the bill appears likely to pass into law during the week beginning March 13th.
Making the Article 50 notification. Once the bill becomes law, the European Treaty is not prescriptive about the form ‘notification’ should take, and our assumption is that May will simply send a letter to the President of the European Council, and make that letter public. The letter is unlikely to go into any specific detail on what the UK thinks should follow, beyond the wish for ongoing cooperation on partnership on many issues.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

An end to EU radio silence. The stricture that the EU should not negotiate with the UK until the formal Article 50 process begins has been followed more uniformly than many expected. Once that notification is made, however, our expectation is that views from national governments and EU bodies on the aims and methods of the negotiations will be more freely expressed. The rider will be that positions within the EU will vary, so exactly how any position is ultimately reflected in that process will be the result of bargaining within the EU as well as with the UK.
SNP Party conference March 17-18. The SNP appears likely to argue that a new referendum on Scottish independence should be held, given May’s desire to exit the single market and the likely absence of any specific consideration of arrangements for Scotland in the Article 50 notification. Indications are that the May administration will resist that call at this point.

PM11:12am

European Council March 25th, and reportedly April 7-8. The Council meeting in Rome at end March is to mark the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, and slated for a first set of reactions to Juncker’s White Paper. There are reports that a special meeting is planned for April 7-8 for the Council to discuss the position on Brexit and give instructions to those who will negotiate on the Union’s behalf, as required by the Treaty. We would expect some clarity on issues such as the sequencing of the talks and the EU’s view on what can be achieved within the two-year time frame to be emerging at this point.

PM11:12am

Done

11:12 am
PM11:12am

you are now updated on the Brexit process

PM11:12am

What a service!

PM11:13am

Hell. I can update you on the ECB if you want

PM11:14am

PM11:14am

Tinsley, Exane

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Some room for satisfaction
The Governing Council of the ECB can be excused for being relatively pleased with how things are progressing in the Eurozone. Inflation is rising and activity appears to have shifted up a gear at the start of 2017. The upcoming ECB staff economic projections are likely to show upward revisions, with Eurozone inflation at or slightly below 2.0% in 2018 and 2019.

But more to do, and risks to manage
However we doubt the ECB or President Draghi will want the market to take too much of a 'hawkish' message. Signs of core inflationary pressures are much less than the headline rates suggest. Meanwhile political risks still require the Governing Council to manage downside scenarios carefully - a tightening in credit conditions would be an unwelcome headwind to growth.

Communication of the exit from unorthodox policy can wait for now
The ECB is operating a number of strands of unorthodox policy, including forward guidance, asset purchases and long term repos. The last TLTRO auction occurred this week and take-up was relatively low. We think the ECB will need to change or remove forward guidance at some point this year, but there is no real need to do so in March. We expect asset purchases to be tapered by December 2017, likely over six months. A cooling in political risk in the second half of 2017 will be time to communicate these changes in our view.

Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 129.80, up 7.6 (+6.22%), High: 132.43, Low: 117.30, Volume: 8.62m

· Management focus: better control and execution, improved customer relationships, simplification of systems, processes and reporting, combined with strong and visible leadership

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Previous management, to be fair.

BE11:21am

Bob Murphy wears a lot of this, having departed at the back of 2016 "to pursue other opportunities".

BE11:21am

Anyway, here's Morgan Stanley to talk us through what's been said.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Following the balance sheet weakness flagged at the 16 February
warning the company has decided to raise £500m by way of rights issue which is fully underwritten on a standby basis and anticipated to complete during 2Q17. The intention is to use the proceeds to pay down borrowings on the revolving credit facilities and more closely align the currency mix of net debt with the currency mix of EBITDA. The terms of the rights issue have not been announced but we note the terms of the June 2016 rights issue (raising £507m at 35.7% discount to TERP). In terms of further balance sheet options, the company is looking at the breadth and shape of the portfolio and will also look at actions on its working capital position.

BE11:22am

The company expresses belief in being able to deliver underlying
operating margins 2-3% higher than current levels, all else equal (11.6% in 2016), based upon Cobham's market positions and on what similar companies achieve. The company indicates the onerous contract provisions, largely relating to KC-46, will weigh on cash over the next two to three years, but beyond the current development cycle the company should be targeting 90% cash conversion.

BE11:22am

As in the 16 February 2017 announcement, the company highlights a wide range of possible outcomes for 2017 performance, and that achievement of 2016 performance (£225m Trading Profit) may be challenging. Whilst no incremental bad news is a positive, and guidance over margin improvement should be supportive, we look for further clarity from the new management team that the group is through the worst of the operational issues in the business.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

To be clear here -- Cobham has announced a £500m cash call with no terms?

PM11:23am

Other than saying it is fully underwritten

PM11:24am

By Merrills and JPM

11:23 am

PM11:24am

BE11:24am

11:25 am

11:25 am

PM11:26am

11:26 am
PM11:27am

(PeterC -- nah, much deeper than that. Sorry i can't share more on an open forum)

BE11:27am

Let me share some Sandy Morris of Jefferies and we can move out of this cul-de-sac.

BE11:27am

For FY17, Cobham repeats there could be a range of outcomes, but that over the medium term Cobham should be able to deliver “operating margins 2-3% higher”. That would see Trading Profit at around £280m. That is not an inspiring number, in our view. We state that in a context of 2H16 divisional performance that causes us to believe the wheels did not come off. The context for the rights issue is essentially the weak 2H16 operating cash conversion, something that appears to have been due to a sharp increase in working capital. At present, we do not know how much of that related to KC-46. Equally, we still have no clear idea of the overall working capital position on KC-46. Hence our statement that a £500m rights issue looks to be strong medicine.

.... Oh, and the sharp-eyed @Dead Cat Bounce notes an email above from from Saeed Baradar of Louis Capital on this very theme.

BE11:31am

Saeed's a seller of BT. Quite an aggressive one.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

I HAVE HAD SOME CLIENTS ENQUIRE ABOUT THE STATEMENT MADE BY DT CEO, TIM HOETTGES THAT BT IS "A HIGHLY INTERESTING" ASSET AND ITS IMPLICATIONS FOR A FUTURE TIE UP BETWEEN BT AND DT - Obviously, BT shares have reacted to that statement and are up slightly (0.6%) in a weak market. To make it very clear, in my view there is no chance of a BT/DT tie up. Given that DT owns 12% of BT and has just written down its value by €2.2bn are we surprised that the CEO of DT might be trying to bid the shares up! As a responsible CEO, he is unlikely to say that he has no interest in BT and will be looking at disposing of his shares (he is locked-up until July anyway) and that there is no possibility in a future corporate actions. He has said what is rational but the reality is very different.

BE11:31am

BT AND DT HAVE DIFFERENT CONTENT STRATEGIES - ONE IS RIGHT - THE OTHER IS WRONG, in my view - I stand in the opposite corner to those who believe that eventually DT is a likely bidder for BT especially if TMOB US is disposed. DT's management content strategy is in total contrast to BT - DT is a content aggregator, rather than the value destroying BT strategy, of over inflated sports content acquisition. Furthermore, with the battle between BT and OFCOM over the legal separation of "Openreach", likely to go to EU and then the uncertainty to continue for years in courts, it is highly unlikely that there will be any M&A deals during that period, and especially not one by a "conservative" management team such as DT's. Does anyone really believe that DT will sell TMOB US, the best international asset of any European operator to buy BT?

BE11:32am

EVEN IF DT WAS INTERESTED, it will not be before TMOB US is disposed and by then BT might be sub 250p, if they continue on their value destroying content strategy. However, I still see a tie up in Europe far more likely for DT, than with BT in a post BREXIT UK. I REMAIN A BUYER OF DT AND SELLER OF BT.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Revenue and profits for 2016 were well ahead of our expectations on the back of growth picking up towards the year end. Management has been very successful at delivering cost savings and has once again raised the cost saving target. We believe improving productivity has become a central plank in the corporate culture of Vesuvius. We believe Vesuvius is currently at or passing the low point in its cycle. Given the substantial improvement in productivity that has been delivered over the past couple of years, we expect the operational leverage on trading profit to be high when volumes start to rise. With close to 13% upside potential to our price, we are raising our recommendation to Overweight from Neutral.

BE11:39am

 Results summary. Reported sales for 2016 were down 6% y/y to £1,401m, 3% above of our forecast, and organic growth was -4%. The FX headwind contributed +10%. Trading profit rose by 7.5% y/y on a reported basis to £133.3m (-1.5% organic); 6% above our forecast. This results in a trading profit margin of 9.5%, up 10bps y/y. EPS for the year increased by 8% y/y to 30.4p which was 9% higher than our above consensus forecast.
 Cost saving target raised by £5m to £35m. Management remains clearly focused on self help and improving productivity. The annualised cost saving target has been increased to £35m, with the full benefit to be delivered by the end of 2017. Given the target is based on a 2014 cost structure, we have assumed that some of the benefits are eroded by rising input costs.
 2017E EPS raised by 13% to 35.2p. The cost saving target has been raised by £5m to £35m. This together with a modest increase in our organic growth expectation, the FX tailwind and a higher revenue/profit base than expected in 2016 translates into a 30bps increase in our 2017E trading profit forecast
and a 13% increase in our 2017E EPS to 35.2p.
 Price target raised to 525p from 377p. We believe Vesuvius is passing the low point in its economic cycle and we are expecting organic volume growth to start to edge higher as we move through 2017. Given this, with the prospect of the risk to our forecasts shifting to the upside, we have raised the EV/EBITA multiple to 10.0x from 9.0x. Together with the 14% increase in our 2018E EBITA forecast translates into a Dec-17 price target of 525p.
 Valuation. Based on our revised forecasts for 2017E, the group is trading on prospective EV/sales, EV/EBIT and PE multiples of 1.03x, 10.2x and 13.2x, respectively, leaving Vesuvius trading at a discount to our industrial universe of greater than 25%.

BE11:40am

Have something a bit longer. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:48am

Overall 2016 P&L is in line, cash is better (what underlies this will be a focus) and the CEO has stepped down. Together this is probably enough for the stock in the short term. There will be questions over further strategic review in due course. Key points: 1) FY 2016 P&L is fine and cash better, Revenue of £4898m is 2% ahead of vs MSe/Cons, 0.1% organic vs MSe/cons -1.1/-1%, EBITA £541m is -1%vs MSe, PBT £475m is -1/-0.1% vs MSe, EPS of 56.7p is -2.5% vs MSe, Net Debt of £1779m compares to MSe £1,998m. 2) The pipeline is £3.8bn and contracts won £1.3bn broadly unchanged since £3.8/1.2bn in Dec. 3) Outlook for 2017 is broadly unchanged with a similar performance to 2016 expected. 4) Exceptional items are £388.3m vs MSe £283m (Impairment of GW £66.6m, Co-op £11m, restructuring is £9.4m higher, impairment of contracts is c £10m higher – all vs MSe). We already had the £50m asset w/o in Dec. 5) No additional cost savings announced £50m announced in Dec. 6) Capita definition of FCF (EBITDA – WC vs EBITA) was £750m vs MSe £656m. This was driven by a WC inflow of £76.1m (£60m ex-one offs) and compares to MSe -£13m. This is a good performance, but we would need to see what is meant by “renegotiating payment terms on certain contracts”. 7) the CEO has stepped down, which may benefit the stock in the ST, but raises questions over further strategic review in due course.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And a line from the conference call.

BE11:49am

Unanswered questions remain, but no more than prior to the results. The obvious concern is the change in CEO, which could elicit a change in strategy and a further contract review process, even though the CFO/chairman highlighted the improvement in monthly contract reporting to the board. In summary, growth remains weak into 2017e, there is risk of a further contract review, IRFS 15 will impact numbers and a return to growth in 2018e looks questionable. The stock is not cheap on 10.5x 2018e EV/EBITA while risk remain.

BE11:50am

So, shares down on the second-half weighting when the company will be under new management and perhaps with an entirely different strategy.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Fair enough.

BE11:57am

11:57 am
PM11:57am

BE11:57am

$2.0 - $3.4bn in US Ad Revenue For Snap By 2021

PM11:57am

get em on record

11:58 am
BE11:58am

There's a lot of work in here about TV overlap and time on the platform and such.

BE11:58am

The ad revenue trends are benchmarked against Cartoon Network/Adult Swim.

PM11:59am

(chad_john -- we are going to hold you to this forecast)

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Let me cut to the conclusion.

BE11:59am

User and usage growth is one of the most significant wild cards of course. While we can imagine scenarios with significant upsides and significant downsides to recent trends, for the present time we are assuming that the company can grow its usage in the United States by half over a multi-year period. On that basis, Snap might have 15% of the equivalent time spent with Facebook, and 15% of Facebook’s US revenue might then be viewed as the upper bound of what’s possible for Snap. We think that Snap can sell its inventory to advertisers at a premium today, but over the longer-run, this won’t necessarily be the case. Other wild cards include whether or not Snap can sustain comparable ad loads, relative ability to provide “performance” ad units where needed the mix of professional content vs. UGC relative to Facebook. And then there is the market power that Facebook (and Google) will have, where the larger platforms will likely continue to capture a disproportionate share of industry revenue given the degree to which they can satisfy advertiser goals and because they will tend to get the first look at the advertiser’s wallet. This factor could bring down the upper share bound to more like 10% of Facebook revenues.

BE11:59am

With these assumptions, Snap’s time as a share of total video would equal around 1.5% of total video time among adults 18-34, or perhaps closer to 3% of time among adults 18-49. For Snap to capture an equivalent amount of TV spend, it would need to demonstrate that the quality of its audience and the quality of its ad inventory is comparable to averages for TV. It would also need to ensure that measurement, impact and executions are broadly similar to what it used for TV. However, there should be upside to this percentage considering the heightened value for a younger audience skew. On the other hand, there is downside if the UGC nature of most content reduced the relative value.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Based upon our estimates for Facebook’s US ad revenue in the year 2021, 10% of this figure would equal $3.4bn. Using our estimates for total television spending, 3% would equate to $2bn in 2021, although it might be more appropriate to include additional estimates we make for non-TV-based digital video, which would push the 3% figure up towards $2.6bn. We would separately add international revenues to these figures, which we assume will broadly follow US trends with a multi-year lag. We note that at Facebook it was roughly five years following the launch of international sales before revenues outside the US matched domestic ones. Meanwhile, at Twitter, six years following the introduction of international sales, domestic revenues are still much larger than international ones despite a larger international user base.

BE12:02pm

The deal values Snapchat at $24B although this number is likely to change multiple times during trading today. Using this number likely puts Snapchat on over 20x F12M revenues although no official street consensus will be available, of course, until late this month. This valuation in itself compares to LinkedIn’s IPO priced at 18x F12M P/S and Twitter at 10x F12M P/S (source: Aviate Global). Twitter’s 12 month trailing revenue run rate at the time of its own IPO was $534M, versus Snapchat’s $404M. But trailing revenue is not a fair comparison when looking at high growth digital businesses and the focus is more on what investors are willing to pay for future growth. (Traditional metrics such as DCF may be the true drivers of value for financial assets long term but for those companies which are high growth and innovative then it is nearly impossible to predict with any accuracy what the long term cash flows can look like for these companies. DCF may be a great theoretical framework, but it isn’t when we don’t have accurate inputs. Revenue to growth is often used as a starting point for private valuation rounds.) If we take the LinkedIn example, while the IPO was priced at 18x F12M P/S the company’s subsequent execution revealed that the deal was, with hindsight, priced at 7.3x “real” revenue numbers having successfully beaten street estimates every quarter.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Cutting to the conclusion, for the sake of not over-sharing Campling's work.

BE12:02pm

There was a time when Tinder was hailed as the great app for the economically attractive younger demographic audience. Yet latest parent results (Match Group) show that despite being the #4 largest global (non-games) revenue app on iOS and Android it only managed $175M revenues in 2016 (Source: Match Investor Relations, App Annie). So we see the same as a cautionary tale to not overplay the connection of usage and ideological success for a rising technology concept to assumed financial and business scale. Facebook has scale, as does Tencent (55% of ALL Chinese internet usage is spent on the Tencent platform). Snapchat does not yet have scale and there are significant risks around opportunity to achieve the same given the firm’s economic moat being attacked aggressively by Facebook.
Over time, whether Snapchat can remain a member of the ‘10x revenue club’ remains to be seen. It is Facebook and Tencent which are the two most worthy ‘members’ of this club in our view.
